column1: Before 4 June 2021, will the United Kingdom's Office for National Statistics (ONS) report that the percentage of working adults who "worked from home exclusively" fell below 20%?
column6: ['Society', 'Health']
Vaccine rollout doing well now doing under 40s. I hopeful there will be no third wave to scupper it all. We will probably have to live through all the variants.

don't see it dropping more than a few percentage points, and currently it's about 26% https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/economicoutputandproductivity/output/bulletins/economicactivityandsocialchangeintheukrealtimeindicators/13may2021#social-impact-of-the-coronavirus
Looks like up to 26% in latest release, seems very unlikely from here.
38% are still working from home exclusively.
Only 2 releases left, last one at 25%, dropping a bit but looking unlikely it'll land below 20%.
Office workers do not consist of the majority of workers, but the link discusses more than 1Million people. The caveat being not exclusively as the question requires.
Still 25pc
Dropping very slightly. On the one hand I think there is likely only one report left. On the other, anecdotally a lot of people are having their offices opened up.
Further adjustment down as the latest figure is 25%. Really can't see this dropping below 20% in the next couple of weeks.
https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/economicoutputandproductivity/output/bulletins/economicactivityandsocialchangeintheukrealtimeindicators/20may2021
I think the crowd is about right.
Maintaining until next report where it should include the May 17 reopening. Beware possibility of lagged public response. Beware possibility that things level off at 20.
"Further rise in VOC-21APR-02 cases detected
passage of time
Dropping 5, no significant drop on most recent release

The 13 May 2021 release shows 26% still "worked from home exclusively" which was unchanged from the prior week. We'll get more reports and, with summer approaching (new cases dropping precipitously, but they did last summer too), there may be significant movement. But right now, it doesn't like the numbers will move fast enough to make a meaningful change. (Presumably, people are also kind of comfortable with the work arrangement they have, so I expect this number to move more slowly than, say, percentage who went out to a restaurant or to a concert or shopping, etc.

It just doesn't look like it's going down fast enough, it probably has a strong relation to the unlocking timetable, and that and more may be in jeopardy with the India/B.1.617 variant now doubling in cases every week. Also anecdotally, people I know are not being moved back to the office yet.
There are two (at least) issues here that could confuse a reliable prediction.
So this data has now moved to a different release Economic activity and social change in the UK, real-time indicators - Office for National Statistics (ons.gov.uk)

I have completely revised this as I had previously forecast that WEFH rates would covary with Covid cases, as they did last year but rates have remained at around 27% for the last few weeks despite a now very low rate of cases. The latest stats have a breakdown as to reasons for people not travelling to work and of the 27% who do not, 55% is due to the employer asking them not to work from home and 47% due to following government guidelines to work from home. Government guidelines to work from home where possible look like they are not going to change despite the easing of restrictions on 17th May so I don't see this figure changing much. Also people who prefer to or normally work from home are probably not probably going to change that much either. Some more workplaces might open but only 25% of respondents said their workplace is closed so even assuming they all stop working entirely from home that's not enough to get the overall percentage to 20 even if they all opened. A drop of that magnitude in WEFH rates happened before (around mid June 2020) but that coincided with a more significant easing of lockdown restrictions and was from a higher level, to get from 27%-20% last year took a couple of months. So I am struggling to see any route to get to 20% by 4 June. If it were to happen it would probably be due to a significant re-opening of workplaces combined with more employers dropping guidance to work entirely from home and significantly increased confidence meaning people choose to take up that option. Simply due to the numbers required and the historical record i am rating this as only a 9% probability and will shift even lower if there's no big drop after the easing if restrictions in May 17th.

Swinging down below 50% based on this week's data. I'd assumed the number would keep falling but it's stalled at 26% this week. There are 3 reports before 4 June so I still there's a chance office visits, meetings, site visits etc increase over the next couple of weeks and push that figure further down, especially as 17 May sees the opening of indoor hospitality and lifting of other restrictions. Anecdotally I see a lot of people who have worked almost exclusively at home since March 2020 now going into the office one day a week or having a day of meetings. If the end date for this question were even two weeks later I'd be more confident and stick to my earlier +50 prediction.
Swinging back down because we all make mistakes.

https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/economicoutputandproductivity/output/bulletins/economicactivityandsocialchangeintheukrealtimeindicators/13may2021 Still at 26pc. May change from 17th when lockdown eases some more. But most likely June. So reducing forecast. But keeping a probability because it’s clear loads of people are already travelling and talking about opening offices up again. Check again on next release on 20th.
Trying to read between the lines,

I still think this could happen within June, but the deadline on 4th is looking just too soon, especially given the guidance dates for easing restrictions. If the deadline was the end of June, I would keep to >50%.
Don't think so! There is so much money to be saved and if you have the space at home and can do it from there, why will you change this dinamic?

Looks like the last release was still 27%. Four releases left and the number may be slowly dropping or holding steady. I'll plan on dropping by 5% every release unless I start seeing a meaningful drop. The release linked in the question doesn't show the percent for the last release but it's available at the Excel spreadsheet from the source data linked at the link below (tab 5, "worked from home and didn't travel to work").

https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/vaccinations +6.6% of the UK population has had at least their first dose in the past month, bringing the total to 67.2%, and +21.1% have had two doses for a total of 33.5%. These trends look pretty linear, so we can roughly estimate that in the next month they'll be sitting at 70-75% of the population with at least one dose, and perhaps over 50% with both doses. While the ONS is definitely showing a move away from WFH (27% as of late April) and an increase in any amount of commuting to work (+2%), given that the UK won't quite be at the numbers associated with herd immunity yet, I would think they stay above 20%. Cases have stabilized and deaths are decreasing though, so things may move faster in this regard. If the +2% trend away from WFH continues or accelerates, it could certainly close the gap between 27% and the target 20%.

Reading the lastest surveys. 60pc of people travel to work already. All numbers about going to work have increased in last couple of waves. Only 8pc expect to go back in next month, with 28pc in 1 to 3 months. This is consistent with the June timeline of lockdown restrictions mostly lifting all constraints. Given this question is due to resolve in 1 month, and the last wave was at 27pc, it is possible, to drop below 20pc, but time is getting tight. Need to see full data next week (this week was a smaller release of info). https://www.ons.gov.uk/businessindustryandtrade/business/businessservices/bulletins/businessinsightsandimpactontheukeconomy/latest https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronavirustheukeconomyandsocietyfasterindicators/6may2021
I am upgrading slightly against the crowd on this one.
Current WFH is 27%: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronavirustheukeconomyandsocietyfasterindicators/29april2021
Bottomline is that the UK is going to be able to do a robust re-opening, but it wcomes down to timing and June 4 is fast approaching.

Anticipate an announcement on how well or not so the opening of non-essential shops has been in terms of case number and hospital admissions in Mid-May. New ways of working have been in place for over 12 months. Those who are fortunate enough to be able to work from home are less inclined to return to the office, which has been the general trend seen by HR in internal back to work surveys.
No change over the last

29/04 = 27pc. Many businesses have no incentive to rush back, but offices opening just for the odd day will start to remove the “exclusive” from responses. Still, going to lower forecast due to timings.
Big drop. Have to acknowledge time is getting tight and despite low cases, the exclusively from home is stubbornly high at 30%. Should drop again if do not see drops in coming weeks.
At 27% with 5 weeks remaining

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-26/almost-half-of-u-k-office-workers-are-back-at-their-desks?cmpid=BBD042621_CEU&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_term=210426&utm_campaign=closeeurope&sref=1mjpCW3y Office occupancy levels across the U.K. topped 40% Tuesday through Thursday last week, reaching a high of 45% on Wednesday, according to data from Metrikus. Think we are slowly getting there.
From ONS: worked exclusively from home remained broadly similar to the previous week at 27%

This report makes me think that, after the lock down, the number of people working exclusively from home is gong to be lower than 20% (https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peopleinwork/labourproductivity/articles/homeworkinghoursrewardsandopportunitiesintheuk2011to2020/2021-04-19). So, the question is how fast the 20% will be reached. Given the goverment plan to come back to normality, I think that chances of being down 20% are not low.

Making the bold leap and saying 'yes' to this finally. The UK's vaccination program has been going well and the explosive wave that swept the country in the winter has subsided + they've put in place good travel restrictions. Leaving at 85% as the figure has to fall 8% from present 28% in 5 weeks. Provided a new vaccine-resistant strain doesn't permeate the border and send them into another wave then I am confidence <20% of people will work exclusively from home, though some percentage of people I imagine will stay at-home full time long term
Down to 28% as of 11 April.
Dialing back down. On the bullish side, the pros have a very high estimate for getting to this number by July (77%): https://goodjudgment.io/economist/#1426 Abd the case load has fallen dramatically:
EDIT: For the week ending 11 April 2021, post-Easter publication with some expected statistical weaknesses states a slight decrease to 28%. This could coincide with recent new step of reopening.
It might be close but I think the tendency favors it given the trends.

Bumping probability up significantly as the question is on whether it will be exclusively from home. The pros also think the odds are 80% this happens by July, so 40% by June isn’t out of the question.

In terms of Government restrictions, it is not until stage 4 (no earlier than June 21) that Covid secure requirements will be reviewed for businesses. From workers preferences, two days paid at home is an expected work pattern. Long hours and virtual meetings are a negative together with a loss of camaraderie in an office based social environment. Aspirations and motivations are diminished. However due to government regulations being led by SAGE will keep the workforce at home until end of June.
dropping by 5% on the latest AstroZeneca difficulties in UK
Re-affirming position. Not much information has come across but continued struggles with getting COVID under control in the UK
Now at 31 but perhaps only one more report (early may) to come out before the deadline. I'll go down at little bit to incorporate consensus but still would put my money on >20%

My expectation is that upcoming changes will primarily affect those that are currently furloughed or can't work from home at present. Table 5: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/healthandwellbeing/datasets/coronavirusandthesocialimpactsongreatbritaindata
Unchanged at 31%, 1st April Report

Objectively, the number of jobs that can be carried out from home is restricted to the administrative and managerial middle classes, a relatively small proportion of the workforce. Most working class jobs need workers to be present (delivery drivers, binmen, tradespeople, gig workers, etc), and there are increasing signs that employers are coming to demand this despite government advice to allow home working. Subjectively, increasingly workers are getting fed up with beig at home, going by social and news media reports, and realising that WFH results in longer working hours and a disruption to any work-life balance, plus promotion chances are lessened if you're not 'on the ground' and working with managers. I strongly expect the numbers WFH to fall in the near future, for economic, social, and workplace reasons. 20% is unsustainably high without enabling measures, such as a Universal Basic Income.

Wave 27 reporting 31pc which is holding steady. 2 months to go and 11pc need to partially go back to the office. 12 April is next milestone which will see if easing lockdown impacts infections. If goes ahead some places will go back to the office. Review after then.

I see a strong indication in Europe that a large number that is stable and more likely growing than falling, is working from home during this pandemic and is openly expressing the intention to do so post-pandemic
In every report I have read the percentage is increasing not decreasing. So if it was 30% it shouldn’t drop below 20
Reducing due to potential supply issues, rising cases elsewhere in Europe and passage of time.
April is 2nd dose month so unlikely to be movement. Think it's a case of sit tight until June 21 ... For those going back to offices.
UK may see a rise in cases just like the rest of the world in the coming months.
England is to enter "phase two of Step1" of its lockdown lifting today 29 March 2021. https://www.deseret.com/2021/2/22/22295356/england-covid-19-lockdown-steps

Nationwide is the first of the firms to announce that their employees can work from anywhere, this may be a start of a trend as new ways of working become entrenched into the workforce. Prediction remains at zero per cent as it was since January. The government has all but confirmed that the vaccination programme will slow down as they negotiation better supply terms with EU. Also, Vaccine passporting plans do not address the major part of the workforce (24-44 year olds) which would not have received their vaccine by the time the country want to open (back) up in June (21st). Without a clear pathway for knowing who has or hasn't received the vaccine, it will be difficult for firm/employers to declare their workplaces are safe and therefore I think many will be reluctant in insisting people return to the offices.
Up 2 points to 32% last week.
New data out and the number is ticking up.

Office based staff based are advised by government guidelines to work from home until June 21. (note: advisory). Although the UK vaccination program has been successful, there will be reticence to avoid a third wave of the virus presently being experienced by EU Nations. The important part of the question is ‘worked form home exclusively’ which considering organisations are looking at reducing office time (1/2 days per week) as opposed to permanently working from home, reduces the numbers substantially.

New York City gets 80,000 employees back to offices - however, it is likely to take a bit longer in the old world. https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9394609/NYC-Mayor-Bill-Blasio-says-80-000-remote-municipal-workers-office-3.html
Spikes in the number of COVID cases.

A tad bit higher due to weekly reports instead of monthly reports, and greater confidence that in the next few weeks the UK population will become more optimistic given no increase in COVID cases in the last 30 days and counting. I think a chance for a climb is slimmer and a chance of it stagnating around 30 to 40—well, I got proved wrong on that assumption. Will decrease if next report shows little change or extreme change upward. Will decrease if reports become unavailable.
The latest report signals a 6pp drop from 36 to 30 in just one week. Do this 2 more times and you'll fall below 20. There is 2 more months to go, with plenty of time for outlier data.
At the risk of confirmation bias, the vaccine delay is probably the last straw on this. Everywhere I know, including my own workplace, are not looking at this until after June 4.

First forecast, gut feeling. Looking at the trend I don't see figures reflecting less than 20% working exclusively from home as 2nd waves hit late in December and the UK is currently under moderate restrictions in March.
Update: Behold . . . my most irresponsible forecast. Way too low.

We would need to see the trend dropping faster than it did between June and September 2020. It took 3.5 months for it to drop from 40 to 20. It is currently around 36 and needs to drop back to below 20. We have 2.7 months left and that might not be enough time because a new report may not come in time. Superforecasters have it at 82 percent 20% or below, but it has decreased from high 80s and is continuing to decrease. Additionally, their question calls for July, not for June, as well as includes the lifting of all lockdown restrictions in June.

Early March survey reports 36pc. Step 3 of lockdown easing currently planned for 17 May means most retail opening and should signify a point when people will start trying to get back to normal. But that is very close to June. I still think a lot of offices will start opening soon for the odd day or small groups of people and so fulfilling the “exclusive” part of this question by June seems a little hard. Maybe I’m jumping the gun a bit, but by that point it will be 15 months of people stuck exclusively at home.

Worked exclusively from home up to 36% as of the date of the survey of March 7th, published March 11th. The survey come from the link below (first link under section 7), and was last updated as of March 7th. Based on the timeline in the second link, it seems like there's no real date planned within the timeline of the lockdown to tell people they don't need to work from home anymore. Based on these two factors I'm going down 15. It seems like people are continuing to work from home, and so far there doesn't seem to be any indication that's changing despite lower case counts. Maybe with more vaccinations that will change, but I expected it to change by now with lower case counts and that didn't work out so I'm trying to counteract that some. Worth noting the superforecasters still appear to think it will drop below 20% by the end date.

Assuming it peaked at 35%, drawing a line of best fit it is currently at 30%, on average. Therefore it has 2/3 of its progress left, with 60% of the question time remaining. Crunch the arithmetic, and I derive at 20%.
Based on ONS data I'm decreasing my estimate.

Am really torn in this case. Despite successful vaccination efforts, it doesn't seem likely that everything will revert to where it was by beginning of June. However, the superforecasters see a 85% likelihood that number will be below 20% by July 1 (https://goodjudgment.io/economist/). So for now, I will stick to the mean (30%) and look out for new publications at https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases

I think that after Easter, there will be a strong desire amongst workforces to commute at least one day a week for mental wellbeing / break from the enforced WFH / start to re-establish a more 'normal' work routine with colleagues. I'm waiting to see if case numbers are being contained over this period.

combination of lessening restrictions, the search for optimism in the vaccine program and COVID fatigue, will make the public more keen to strive for normality at work; Government regulation around workplace safety often creates a "sense of safety" and being able to abdicate responsibility to employers and government for their safety. Real Estate projections have also shifted away from the conversion of Business/commercial property to residential property and a suggesting that these spaces will be re-occupied soon. There is no evidence that the last year has permanently shifted how we work.

I know the Supers are very high but the difference between June and July is massive - effectively a different question altogether. I am not aware of any organisations where workforce can be home-based even looking at this yet and restrictions not being fully lifted until June 21st.

As many workplaces are expected to resume as a result of the end of lockdown, the expectation is that the majority will go back to work. There is however still a large amount of people who having started working from home, will want to continue if their company allows it. I don’t think that value will drop below 20% by June as it is quite close.
https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/healthandwellbeing/bulletins/coronavirusandthesocialimpactsongreatbritain/latest

What data are people reading that is driving this prediction so low? I am looking at the UK's success vaccinating at risk population and reducing cases through a single dose strategy. I don't expect the work exclusively from home number to change much between now and 29 March when the stay at home order is lifted. If the number stays above 30% after 29 March my thesis may be wrong. Until then, keeping my prediction at consensus + 25%.
Seasonal employment will help adjust for layoffs and other firings.
Update - No change for probability
Down 5% over the last two weeks. Expect that to continue as schools return over the next couple of weeks. Both from teachers and parents being more willing to go in.
Reducing forecast due to the 21st June timeline for reducing restrictions.
I'm not sure what I was thinking when I had it at 90% last December
The pros are at 84% [1] and I agree but moving -5% to stay within my risk tolerance vs crowd.
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-56158405

Superforecaster version of this question is in upper 80s probability for JULY whereas this question is JUNE, which is in approximately 90 days. My understanding is that half of those currently working from home exclusively need to switch out in order to go below 20%, which sounds like an achievable task in the next 12 weeks.
Even with speedy rollout, Seems unlikely given London currently in lockdown

Just a couple of months too early. The goal seems to be 21st June, and it doesn't make sense to move jobs that can be done just as well at home back to the office until the very end. Anecdotally I can say that companies are not even having these discussions yet.
Still think the pros are right [1] but reducing my risk relative to the crowd. Note that users I'm following range from 10% to 75% with 65% average and 70% median.
The goverment wants to examine working from home orders on June 21. Reducing my forecast accordingly. https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/uk-news/work-home-advice-end-according-19892096

New lockdown phase out announced does not ease full restrictions until June at the earliest. I think this means offices will just continue to work from home a lot. But people just can’t cope so still think some going into the office even for the odd day here or there will start changing the figures. Reducing forecast a little.

The UK has administered about 18 million doses as of Feb 19th with 14 million doses (not sure how many are first vs second dose, but they've been prioritizing first doses) between Jan 15 and Feb 15, at a fairly steady pace. The UK's total population sits at around 68 million people, so, conservatively, if vaccination speed does not pick up and we assume everyone is getting 2 doses, that means 50% of the population will be vaccinated by the beginning of June. On the other side according to https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2020/oct/26/the-great-rebalancing-working-from-home-fuels-rise-of-the-secondary-city (I fully admit to not reading all the sources referenced), about 31% of UK jobs can be performed from home, and 86% of employers have indicated their intention to implement WFH to at least some degree post-pandemic. But how much will be exclusively WFH? Given the vaccination trajectory, it's like that a majority of people would have received at least a single dose by June 4th, though I doubt this will lead to a lifting of restrictions (or suggestions) by then, so I see it unlikely there would be huge progress towards whatever the post-pandemic "steady state" will be (which I do think will be <20% exclusively WFH and probably closer to 10-15%).

If I understand the Excel download https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/healthandwellbeing/datasets/coronavirusandthesocialimpactsongreatbritaindata correctly, 37% "worked from home and didn’t travel to work" from 10 to 14 February 2021. Will it fall below 20%, almost to half this value, by June? Kinda don't expect it, but I guess I am going closer to the Crowd (30 > 40). (Not really sure why the Superforecasters https://goodjudgment.io/economist/ are so bullyish about it; their resolution date is July 1 instead of June4, still...)

-5 on February report showing 37% as worked exclusively from home. To me the big test will be the March report as I think it will have been enough time for people's behavior to adjust to the large decline in cases. If next month hasn't shown a decent sized drop in exclusively working from home I'll revise downward significantly.
https://metro.co.uk/2021/02/17/staff-to-be-told-to-keep-working-from-home-even-after-lockdown-eases-14095100/

Latest reporting from ONS has figure at 36pc. Increased since my last review, but again June is quite a way away and logic from last forecast holds, summer, can we go more than a year totally remotely ( 11 months as of yesterday), mental health, vaccines and human nature. Going to reduce my forecast a bit as everything COVID related has lasted longer than we think, but I still think once we get to Easter and the schools reopening it’ll get more difficult not to look to moving to a half way post COVID world which will mean a lot more people, starting to go back to the office, at least partially and that’s all this question is asking.
Still think the pros are right [1] but reducing my risk relative to the crowd.

Given the prolonged period in which the nation has been homeworking, significant steps have been put in place to ensure that business have been able to continue working. This includes cost outlay on laptops. enhanced software and home working suppliers (secondary monitors etc.). In addition to this, the cost crunch of reduced income for many businesses will lead to a cost saving drive, initially led by the move away from expenses office rentals and by utilising the equipment already purchased for home working capabilities. In addition the UK government looks increasingly to be moving towards a slow unlock model whereby existing precautions (such as use of mandatory face masks and social distancing) will remain in place. Given the space required to effectively implement 2m social distancing and the associated lack of headcount within the office the touted benefits of returning to the office (camaraderie, enhanced collaboration) will be moot.
Maybe interpreting this question wrong. Why would they go back to <20% before 04/06? It’s only has advantages (even apart from covid)... if the question was before 2025 i would only give 50%...
Looking less likely. Feb number was flat at 36%
According to the latest ONS report 36% of adults worked from home exclusively. This is the highest percentage since June.
downgrading given the uptick of WFH in February
Forgot to consider the delay between vaccination and a fall in cases.
Updating due to ongoing concern about variants and subsequent efficacy of the vaccines.

New variants are affecting the vaccination programmes around the world with some showing low impact in the younger population, the group most likely to suffer from mild/moderate disease and spread the virus. Currently, the strategy is for lockdowns and vaccinations. Due to this new information, lockdown could continue through March and affect April/May/June, as the vaccine strategy is refined and new/modified vaccine programmes with better efficacy are rolled out.

The proportion didn't decrease below 20% last summer when cases were low. While we may see good vaccination rates by 4 June 2021, I don't think that will be enough to convince people and companies to return to the office.

In 2019, 5% of the workforce worked mainly from home which probably provides the pre-pandemic floor to this figure. The rate hit 20% in August and early September 2020, which looks at the sustainable home working floor for during the pandemic. Prior to the pandemic, 13% of the working population reported working at home in the week prior to interview which suggests that there is a substantial proportion of the workforce who could continue working at home.

20% is the lowest rate of exclusively working from home which was reached in September 2020. Roughly this seemed to covary with the number of cases though there was a slight lag as by then the second wave was starting. In Dec the percentage was 28%, slightly less than earlier in 2020 possibly reflecting the slightly less stringent terms of the lockdown at that point. So I think the base rate is that it takes about 6 months from peak cases to WFH going down to 20%, which absent other factors makes it reasonable to plump for 4 June as roughly when cases might again drop to that level. However the major difference is the vaccine rollout, it won't have reached most of the working population by then but I think it will mean it's a good bet cases and hospital admissions will be down further this 6months than after the first peak. So tilting estimate more towards less than 20% WFH.
Small bump on the back of the large scale roll out of lateral flow tests.

Working from home numbers were down to 33% last June[1] and down to 25% last August[2]. 7-Day-Averages were in June as in August around 1000 cases only in July there was a significantly lower 7-Day-Average around 600. This concludes that employees return to work shifted on month from falling case number. If we assume that the vaccination campaign goes well restrictions could eased by April[3]. Including the one month shift most employees would probably return to work in May. I think cases will be still a lot higher than in last July but because of a lower death rate it is safer and more accepted to go back to work. A lot of the employers seem to want their employees to be at least partly back in office [4]. Opposing to this are the fact that we don't know if vaccine blocks transmission, the development of new strains and problems with the vaccination program.
According to the latest ONS report 34% of adults worked from home exclusively. This is higher than the November level and not rapidly decreasing.
Moving toward consensus, no real information on trends except vaccinations.
Increasing on the naive observation that the new cases and deaths are falling in the UK.
From October 1, 2020 (24%) to December 20, 2020 (28%), an increase of 4% of people are working exclusively from home.
Won't take much to dip below given so near, with optimistic trends. Not that many jobs would require staying home, and UK presumably has many urban jobs requiring work outside of home.

Unlikely. That would require the UK response to be more effective. The strategy of delaying the two jabs option that the UK gov is trying to do hasn't worked in Israel. The new strains are also more lethal. There seems to be movement also to keep kids out of school longer, meaning parents will be at home, so childcare is an issue.

-15 on January report, but cases are dropping so I still think there is a good chance of this. The real test will be the next couple months reports as cases decline. If exclusively work from home doesn't begin to decrease toward the lower 20s in the next couple months then I'll revise downward.

The percentage of people working exclusively from home dropped to 20% in late August and early September 2020 https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronavirustheukeconomyandsocietyfasterindicators/1october2020. The successful rollout of the vaccine, lockdown fatigue and the fact that there are fewer people working from home or furloughed in this third lockdown compared to the first leads me to think there will be more in-person meetings, visits to the office, events etc from Spring onwards, even if many office workers will continue to work from home most of the time for the foreseeable future.
Dropping it with passage of time and delays in mainland European vaccination rollout, which will have knock on effects.
Vaccine going well. Feel happy with my previous forecast.

Reported yesterday that scientists are unclear whether the vaccine will break the chain of transmission [1] which would be essential for a return to normal working practices. UK government is unable to confirm exactly when Lockdown measures will be lifted [2], whether spring or summer or whether on track in reaching vaccination target [3]. Much like the track and trace app, there has been much debate on whether a COVID vaccine passport [4] would have widespread uptake by companies in an effort to get their workforce back on site. Return to the workplace is likely to be a phased process, requiring significant warning and period of adjustment, this will be clearer by 31st March.

Logged in to reduce my risk on this question relative to the crowd but reaffirming instead. Sticking with the pros [1] who are even more confident than I though the resolution dates do not align exactly. Also, leaving a link to the current ONS bulletin [2] for easy retrieval.

The pre-pandemic level was ~5% and it would be reasonable to assume that it will level-off at a level considerably above this figure after the pandemic. However, it dropped to 20% in September 2020 before rising again. Whether more people than in September will be back at work at least some of the time is dependent on some very uncertain factors such as the population-wide efficacy of the vaccine, smoothness of vaccine roll-out, and success of the present lockdown on flattening the curve. Greater clarity on these factors should emerge in the coming weeks when it should be possible to update this forecast.

There are several issues at play here that could affect the return of workers from home-based offices to their original place of work, with advantages and disadvantages for the employee and the company. Large companies have been looking to reduce office space and its ancillary costs (cleaning , security, utilities etc) therefore costs by moving some personnel to remote locations (home). An example of this is Linklaters the UK Law firm. A disadvantage to the company, especially its middle management would be the loss of control and supervision, although this could be countered by employees being paid by production of work (having been pre-packaged), rather than the time being present in the office. The advantages to the employee would be the avoidance of the daily drudgery and cost of commuting and a better life balance (depending on family relations, children, pets etc). The disadvantages to the employee would the loss of the office camaraderie and peer-based support and learning plus the potential of the company to turn its business into a gig style economy with potential loss in holiday, sickness benefits. The company ‘mission statement could probably be dispensed with (a plus). This separation of some employees to a home-based system could have a silver lining in that discrimination in its various forms (age, gender, race, disability etc) could be eradicated. A further issue is that some employees may not be able, or have the inclination to work alone, at home. Therefore, a simple forecast as to the percentage of workers working from home is somewhat complex and my proposal at this time would be a figure below 20%.

There is a possibility to see a drop in the number of people working from home exclusively. However, given the nature of these works and the opportunity that some companies are seeing in reducing their rental property expenses, going below 20% from 30% is highly unlikely.

Since at least the 23rd of March (date of full lockdown) this has been over 20%, even after pubs reopened in July (if you can use that as the definition of relative normalcy during Covid). So the only reason it should be dropping below is because the UK's vaccination rollout progresses quickly. Assuming, the UK needs to vaccinate everyone above 65 (12 million people) and then say 40% of all 16-64 years olds (40m), which would give you coverage of 40% (probably below the minimum needed https://www.ajpmonline.org/article/S0749-3797(20)30284-1/fulltext), that would take 104 million doses. If you add to the fact that it takes a month to confer full immunity (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-55181665), it is a lot to ask. That said the speed at which everything is moving and the desire for as much normalcy as possible means for the moment I will base it at 40% until I have more colour on the rollout.
